instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no TPAD or KB
threads.message:
This board was an insurance write off, I can't remember the history it's been in the draw.

Tried new trackpad and keyboard cable and new trackpad. KB powers machine.

J4801 voltages.
Pins:
1 = 3V3
3 = 3V3
5 = gnd
7 = 2V28
9 = 3V3
11 = 0V
13 = 0V1
15 = 3V3
17 = gnd
19 = gnd
21 = 3V3
23 = 5V
25 = 5V
27 = gnd
29 = gnd
31 = gnd
33 = gnd
35 = 8V6
37 = 8V6
39 = 8V6
41 = 8V6

2 = 0V
4 = 0V
6 = 0V
8 = 3V27
10 = 3V3
12 = 0V
14 = 5V
16 = 3V3
18 = gnd
20 = 0V
22 = 3V3
24 = 5V
26 = 3V3
28 = gnd
30 = gnd
32 = gnd
34 = 0V
36 = 8V6
38 = 8V6
40 = 8V6

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no TPAD or KB
threads.message: <SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI_MOSI</SIGNAL> should be 3.3V, it has a pull up resistor, check <RESISTOR>R4801</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R1667</RESISTOR>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ACTUATOR_DISABLE_L</SIGNAL> should be 3.4V this comes from SMC, measure in diode mode red probe to ground

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no TPAD or KB
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no TPAD or KB
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 17564"]<SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI_MOSI</SIGNAL> should be 3.3V, it has a pull up resistor, check <RESISTOR>R4801</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R1667</RESISTOR>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ACTUATOR_DISABLE_L</SIGNAL> should be 3.4V this comes from SMC, measure in diode mode red probe to ground[/QUOTE]

<RESISTOR>R1667</RESISTOR> on <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> side is 3V3 but on <SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI_MOSI</SIGNAL> side = 0V.
Connection good <RESISTOR>R1667</RESISTOR> to <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
Connection good from <RESISTOR>R1667</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R4801</RESISTOR>. Also checked for short to gnd, no short.
<RESISTOR>R1667</RESISTOR> = 46k

<SIGNAL>SMC_ACTUATOR_DISABLE_L</SIGNAL> = 0v and diode mode to gnd = 0.7V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no TPAD or KB
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no TPAD or KB
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST</SIGNAL> should of course not be low.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no TPAD or KB
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 17600"]<SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST</SIGNAL> should of course not be low.
[/QUOTE]

All I can see on this line is a 100k to ground and a connection to <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>... What's meant to pull <SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST</SIGNAL> hi?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no TPAD or KB
threads.message: Disconnect flat cable and measure diode mode on all SPI lines. Measure resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>LSOC_RST</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no TPAD or KB
threads.message: Did you try new TP/KB and cables. I'm not sure if a working keyboard is needed to make TP work.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no TPAD or KB
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 17617"]Did you try new TP/KB and cables. I'm not sure if a working keyboard is needed to make TP work.[/QUOTE]

Tried cables and keyboard did cross my mind but I only have one other definitely fucked keyboard for this machine. I'll put it back in the draw till something comes along to test the possibility of needing a KB for TPAD to work

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no TPAD or KB
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 17616"]Disconnect flat cable and measure diode mode on all SPI lines. Measure resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>LSOC_RST</SIGNAL> too.[/QUOTE]

OK, I'll try that before I out it away again.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no TPAD or KB
threads.message: Keyboard can be fucked as long as the electronics in it are ok. There is a controller on the KB and sleep sensor too.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no TPAD or KB
threads.message:
Note to self: when buying after-market cables always buy more than one.

It was a bad cable. I have fitted another and it works.
Please mark solved.
